qas.question: Who provided a humorous example of the unreliability of back-translation?
For what language did Twain create a back-translation?
What include a synopsized adaptation of Twain's story?
What had been thought for a while to be an independent ancient Greek precursor to Twain's story?
Who provided a boring example of the unreliability of back-translation?
What language did Twain remove a back-translation?
What lacked a synopsized adaptation of Twain's story?
What had been thought for a while to be a dependent ancient Roman precursor to Twain's story?

context: <a0_0><b5_0>Mark Twain<b5_0/><a0_0/> provided humorously telling evidence for the frequent unreliability of back-translation when he issued his own back-translation of a <a1_0><b6_0>French<b6_0/><a1_0/> translation of his short story, "The Celebrated Jumping Frog of Calaveras County". He published his back-translation in a <a2_0><b7_0>1903<b7_0/><a2_0/> volume together with his English-language original, the French translation, and a <a3_0><b8_0>"Private History of the 'Jumping Frog' Story"<b8_0/><a3_0/>. The latter included a synopsized adaptation of his story that Twain stated had appeared, unattributed to Twain, in a Professor Sidgwick’s Greek Prose Composition (p. 116) under the title, <a4_0>"<b9_0>The Athenian and the Frog"<b9_0/><a4_0/>; the adaptation had for a time been taken for an independent ancient Greek precursor to Twain's "Jumping Frog" story.
